BABES IN TOYLAND
A Musical Comedy in
three acts.
---------

titlePage.docAuthor:
[Handwritten
Books & Lyrics by Glen MacDonough
Music by Victor Herbert
Produced 13 Oct. 1903, at the Majestic Theatre in New York, but this is a later version.]

castGroup.head: CAST
castGroup.castItem: THE WIDOW PIPER, A lonely widow with fourteen children.
HILDA, A maid of all work for the Piper family.
INSPECTOR MARMADUKE, Of the Toyland Police.

note.stage: Scene I: Country fete in Contrary Mary's garden.
Scene I: The Christmas Tree Grove in Toyland.
The Courtyard of the Toyland Palace of Justice.

div.head: ACT I
div.stage: SCENE I: The scene shows the garden of Contrary Mary near the Widow Piper's home. A cask of ale and decorations and pennats and bunting suggest a fete. A party of peasants as the scene is revealed.
No. 1. -- Country Dance and entrance of the Chorus.
UNCLE BARNABY enters at the end of the dance, smirking and bowing right and left. The peasants snub him.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Enjoy yourselves, enjoy yourselves, my dear friends. I am delighted to see you so happy. Are the Piper children here - and especially Contrary Mary?

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: No, Master Barnaby, Mary didn't come to the Fete.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: That's strange, I'm giving it to please her -- and to make you all a little fonder of me.

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Why, are you our host?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Only yesterday he seized poor old Mother Hubbard's house and turned her into the road, all for a debt of a few shillings!

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: Let's finish the afternoon by putting Barnaby under the town pump!

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Hurrah!
sp.stage: (Start to take Barnaby away. TOM TOM ENTERS UP R.)

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Hi! Tom Tom, just in time!

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: What for?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: To save me from the town pump! Stop 'em, my boy, stop 'em, don't let 'em hurt your future brother-in-law!

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: What you? Which of my sisters had caught your miserly eye?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: It's Mary --willful, but entrancing Mary!

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: YOU want to marry Contrary Mary? You might as well try to turn off the sun and blow out the stars!
But let him go, friends, as a favor to me! We may be relatives yet.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Ah! Then there's hope for me with Contrary Mary?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Not a gleam, but some day, you may be my uncle-in-law!

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: If you mean my niece Jane? She and Alan are at the bottom of the sea.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: I don't believe it!

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: They'll never come back to their broken-hearted Uncle Barnaby!

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: And what's their broken-hearted Uncle Barnaby going to do with their fortune?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: I'm keeping it for them --the law forces me to do tat.

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Trust you to take good care of money. You skinflint! But you'll be wise if you take better care to keep out of our way hereafter. Now go! (They all jeer and threaten him)

div.stage: (TOM picks up his staff and bundle from steps of house. HILDA enters from house left.)

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: Master Tom Tom where are you going?

sp.speaker: Tom Tom
sp.p: Hilda, I'm going to find the girl I'm in love with - Jane.

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: Old Barnaby's niece? ---(Gonzorgo and Roderigo enter up right) But wasn't she lost at sea with her brother Alan?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Old Barnaby says so, and that's why I don't believe it.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: But me and my sad faced companion can prove it. We were the sole survivors of the wreck.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: And who are you?

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: I was in charge of the ship, my name is Gonzorgo. (Pointing to Roderigo.) This is my mate and friend to boot.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: Yes, friend to boot!

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: We swear by our right hands (They raise left hands) everyone was lost on the ship but us.

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: I don't think they're telling the truth!

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Nor do I! (Looking instantly at both of them) I remember seeing you two some place before, where was it?

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: You don't by any chance go in for the three B's do you?

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Yes, the three B's. Bridge, Bank Nite and Bingo!

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: I saw you at the Village Fair. You were running the carasel. And you offered to wager you could pick the horse that would come in first.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: You can't accuse us of cheating, it must have been two other scoundrels. Defend yourself!

div.stage: (Attacks TOM, who parries with his staff and knocks Gon's sword from his hand as WIDOW PIPER ENTERS from the house L.)

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: Oh, Mrs. Piper, you're just in time!

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Tom, don't be rude to the gentleman!

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Madam, is he your little boy?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Yes, he is the black sheep of our family -- but I love him!

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: He can't be the white-haired boy and still a black sheep.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: Maybe she's color blind.

sp.speaker: Gon
sp.p: Because of that, I spare him.

div.stage: (Picks up sword, TOM & HILDA GO UP STAGE)

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Accept the blessings of a lonely widow!

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Have you been lonely long?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Two years.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: And have you only the white-haired black sheep to love?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: No, he has 13 sisters and brothers who need a father's care.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: That's a lot of work for one caretaker.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Fourteen children! And - (Points to house) Is this where you call the Convention to order?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Piper left us very well off. And this is our cottage. (Gonzorgo and Roderigo look at each other)

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: I adore the country, don't you?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: I have to.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Did you ever try to rent an apartment in the City with 14 children?

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: And when the nestlings have all flown away, have you ever thought of mating once again?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Well, of course I've had my moments. Will you gentlemen enter and partake of some refreshments?

sp.speaker: Gon. & Roderigo
sp.p: Will we!? We will.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: I married once for money. If I wed again, it will have to be an artist, a poet, or a hero.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: I'm not an expert accountant, but did you say you had 14 children?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Yes, fourteen.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Your second husband would have to be a hero.

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: I'll look for the children, Master Tom, and tell them you're going away.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Thank you, Hilda. (HILDA exits up Left)

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Why, sister Bo Peep, you have the saddest face I've ever seen.

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: I missed most of the party, because I lost my sheep.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: That's nothing for you to feel sheepish about - don't cry, little Bo Peep, don't cry.

div.stage:
SONG #2.
(TOM, BO PEEP, PIPER CHILDREN & CHORUS.)
(During the song, JILL and OTHER PIPER CHILDREN ENTER)

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: I've just found out why old Barnaby is paying for this party.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: He wants everybody on hand to hear his engagement announcement.

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: Engagement? To whom?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Contrary Mary.

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: Oh, Mary hasn't gone and done a dreadful thing like that?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Not yet. But mother's set on the match, and is going to announce the engagement anyway. (ALL express anger)

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Let Barnaby keep his old party! I'm going back to tidy up the stable! (Starts up L. to exit. Others stop her.)

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: Party! He can't buy us with lemonade and chocolate eclaires, can he girls?

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: No! (JILL sits on stage down L.C.)

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: I hope all of you will keep out of trouble till I get back. (Starts up Right)

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Away this very hour to look for Jane!

sp.speaker: Miss Moffett
sp.p: (One of the Piper children) Do keep out of that awful forest! They say there's a veil in it filled with spiders.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: I will, Little Miss Moffett, no spiders for you eh? I know how tough it was on the tuffet.

sp.speaker: Miss Moffett
sp.p: (Shuddering) I don't like to see spiders. When you've seen one of them you've seen them all.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Well I'm off on my hunt for Jane. Who'll go as far as the turn of the road with me? (Starts up right)

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: All of us!

div.stage: (HILDA ENTERS from house left, with small package in hand)

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: Wait, Master Tom, you mustn't go around the world hungry. Here's a box of sandwiches with jelly and pickle.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Thank you, Hilda. And good-bye! Come along, boys and girls. (EXITS with ALL except HILDA and Jill)

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: Goodbye! Goodbye! Just think, he's leaving his native home land. He'll be like a man without a country. What can be worse than that!

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Nothing "except a country without a man".

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: He's going around the world to find his sweetheart. (JANE ENTERS up L. in gypsy boy's costume)

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: And everybody knows that Jane is under the ocean.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Everybody except Jane!

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: You? It isn't you, is it?

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Hilda, it simply can't be anybody else!

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: Where's Alan?

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: He stopped to pin up a tear in his skirt.

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Skirt?

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: After the shipwreck, our clothes were in tatters-- but we met a band of gypsies that gave us what clothing they could spare. And we had to arrange it thus. (Indicates costume)

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: And here's Alan, a regular gypsy!

div.stage: (ALAN ENTERS dressed as a gypsy girl with tambourine swinging from waist.)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Hilda and Jill! Would you know me?

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: Never, Alan, if I hadn't been told.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I am Floretta - until further notice--Floretta, the Fawn of the Forest. (Pirouettes)

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: How is our Uncle Barnaby?

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Your Uncle Barnaby is well.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: And Contrary Mary?

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: Still waiting for a certain young man to come back from being drowned.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Where's Tom Tom?

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: Just started to find you. Quick! If he hasn't gone too far, we can catch him! (Points off R)

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Don't go away, Alan, and look out for the Widow Piper. Remember you're not too popular, with Mary's mother. Hilda and Jill, let's hurry! (HILDA, JILL & JANE EXEUNT quickly up right)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Ah. here you are now!...I mean, do you want your palm read?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: A gypsy! Yes I will have my fortune told. Can you tell fortunes?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Better than an income tax collector. I peek into the future at 25 cents a peek. (WIDOW gives Alan money)

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: There, peek for me!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Your name is Piper! You've had an unfortunate marriage.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Can you tell that by the lines in my hand?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: No, by the lines under your eyes. Your husband is dead. He was not very handsome, he had A. & P. eyes. One eye faced the Atlantic and one eye faced the Pacific. You have a daughter named Mary. She should marry a young man whose name begins with A. He has a lovely character, is charming, gifted and attractive.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: If you're talking about a wretched, no-account young fool named Alan, you're all wrong.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: No, I am -- that is he is -a character every one could love. I'd even love him myself,-- that is, if I knew him.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: I don't think this is such a very good reading.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I could do better with tea leaves....if you could bring me a cup of tea....and perhaps some hot biscuits...I also read the future by hot buttered biscuits.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Go ahead, Gypsy, and tell me more about myself. (Gonzorgo enters from house.) I have two suitors - which shall I marry?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I must see them first. (Widow points to Gonzorgo)

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: There is one!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Well, if that is one, I'd advise you to take the other.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: What have we here, a gypsy?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Yes. Let her read your hand.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: I give you my hand, to find out if she- (Indicating widow) Will give me her hand.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: But first you must take off your glove.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: I'm not wearing gloves, my hands are sunburned.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Yes, expecially the palms. (Looks in hand) Oh, I can't go on! After you've had your hands read will your face be red!

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: I know you see there a mad love and devotion.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Yes, I can see you returning home at night and this lady with her fourteen children, waiting to greet you on the front porch.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Yes...

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Yes, and your present wife and triplets waiting for you on the back porch!

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Gonzorgo! You! You are married?

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Well, yes, and no!

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Make up your mind!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: He has a wife. And his wife's feet are always so tired, her toes want to turn in!

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: It's false. (To Widow) Dost doubt Gonzorgo?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: I dost.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: She dosts, and the sooner you dust the better.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: You don't know what a service you've done me, you've torn the mask from his face. Thank you so much, thank you so much, Floretta, the Fawn! (EXITS INTO HOUSE)

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: So, you are the Fawn! --Well, there goes my deer and my doe! You are a gypsy with the accent on the gyp. (EXITS into house)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Not bad, for the Fawn of the forest. (Pirouettes)

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: We couldn't find Tom Tom.

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: If you need any clothes the children have plenty to spare. (Female chorus begins to enters) (JANE remains on)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Get me some boys togs. I feel it would be well for Floretta to vanish. (HILDA EXITS into house L.)

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: A gypsy!

sp.speaker: 2nd Girl
sp.p: Perhaps a fortune-teller!

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: Do you tell fortunes?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Do I? It was destined by the stars that I was to be a fortune- teller. My father was born under the sign of the crab, and I was born under the sign of the bull. I can tell you everything except the size of the National debt.

div.stage: (ALAN and singing CHORUS all exeunt after song)

sp.speaker: 1st Dandy
sp.p: I don't see anything of her anywhere.

sp.speaker: 2nd Dandy
sp.p: Contrary Mary always works at her garden at this house. (HILDA enters from house)

sp.speaker: 1st Dandy
sp.p: Is Miss Mary at home?

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: No, she's at school. She's taking a course in domestic silence.

sp.speaker: 2nd Dandy
sp.p: You mean domestic science.

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: No, she's going to cooking school.

sp.speaker: 1st Dandy
sp.p: We merely dropped in to inquire about her garden.

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: It's doing very well, thank you.

div.stage: (BO PEEP AND OTHER PIPER CHILDREN ENTER)

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: Oh, look, aren't you Mary's Beaux?

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: We are!

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: There's quite a crowd to see Mary.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: And I just love crowds!

sp.speaker: All the Beaux
sp.p: Mary!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: I'm glad to see you all collectively. Won't you make yourselves at home?

sp.speaker: 1st Beaux
sp.p: Mary, is it true that you are going to marry?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Of course I'm going to marry....

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: That is - some day! I don't know when or to whom!

sp.speaker: 2nd Beau
sp.p: Can't you make a choice now?

sp.speaker: 1st Beau
sp.p: Yes, each one of us is proposing to you.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: I'll consider your offer. But here's what I expect from the man I could really love.

div.stage:
SONG: #4.
(Cho. of Dandies and Children, and Dance)
(All exeunt on number except MARY. Enter BARNABY up right with large bouquet.)

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Here, pretty one, is a bunch of pretty blosoms, and I only wish they were as pretty as you.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: I've hidden a tender little note in that bouquet. I'll go away and let it speak for me. (Goes R)

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Oh, say it yourelf, and have it over with!

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Sit down. (They sit on bench) Don't be cruel, Mary. Won't you marry me? (Takes her hand) I know the bloom is no longer on my cheek---

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Pardon me, but there's nothing wrong with your cheek.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: You may be treating me this way in the hopes that Alan will come back and marry you. Take my word for it, you'll never see him again.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: How I wish I could say the same of you. (GONZORGO and RODERIGO enter from house)

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Here's proof! The very men in whose tender care I placed my niece and nephew. Now do you believe me?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: I'll neither believe you nor marry you! (Starts toward house) Not if you were the last man on earth! Not if you gave me steam yachts - castles, or the richest jewelry. My foot is down! That foot -- the other foot -- both feet! (Exits into house)

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Well, are you ready to settle with your silent partners?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: I don't understand you.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: You can hear us, even if we are your silent partners. And here's what we want to broadcast to you. How about our contract to get rid of your niece and nephew?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: What have you done with Jane and Alan?

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: They are now playing harps with Saint Pete and his golden Gaters. (Roderigo sobs) We chartered an old dilapidated schooner and we lured Alan and Jane on board, we told them it was the show boat. (Roderigo sobs) The boat was an old dilapidated wreck that we christened "Static". We knew the schooner would soon be under the foam. (Roderigo sobs) The weather bureau said it would be clear weather but we knew they were wrong as usual. Soon it began to rain - it rained cats and dogs, - I know because I stepped in several poodles. (Roderigo sobs) We knew if the storm struck -- the waves would strike -- and the crew would go on a sit-down strike. Well, IT did - - they did -- and we did. Down went the hull of the Ship. (Roderigo sobs)

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: You mean the whole of the ship.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Hull or whole- what is a little pronunciation among friends? The ship sank! And everyone but us two are now sleeping on the ocean bed with oysters as pillows.
What are you crying for?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: I've seen the last of my little charges.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: And now you'll see the first of ours. (Presents bills)

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: A bill?

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: My little charges for disposing of your little charges.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: 500 dollars!?

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: For scuttling one ship.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: What part of it did you do?

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: I was 1st vice-president in charge of the scuttle department.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Follow me down to my office, I am the manager of the T.C.N.P.U. --Finance Company. There is much money in my vault.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: The T.C.N.P.U. finance company? What does the T.C.N.P.U. stand for?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: They Can Never Pay Up!

div.stage: (JANE & ALAN ENTER in school children's dress, from house.)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Remember Jane, when we meet Mary, two is company, and three - is a conference.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Don't worry. I know when I'm not wanted. (Sees bouquet left by Barnaby. Picks it up) What a pretty bouquet! (Sniffs at it) M'm. How sweet! (Hands it to Alan)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Wonder where it came from. What's this? (Takes card from heart of bouquet) A card. (Glances at it)

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: "To darling Mary". "From her future husband."

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Oh, Alan! In your absence have you been jilted?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I'll never speak to her again!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.stage: (Backing in from house and calling off)
sp.p: I won't dress for the party, I won't! I won't!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Alan!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Oh Mary! (With a sudden change of manner) How do you do, Miss Piper?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Very well, thank you. Don't you think we need rain?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Yes--a change. Some people can't get along with change. (Pointing to bench) Won't you sit down?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Thank you. (They sit stiffly)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I haven't seen you for some time.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: You've been away, haven't you?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Have you really noticed it?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: It just occurred to me.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: It's a warm day.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Chilly, isn't it?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Very. (Archly) I think I need something around me. (Repeats louder) I think I need something around me.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I heard what you said. (Slides to other end of bench)

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Alan, I don't understand such behavior.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Better ask your future husband to explain it!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: My future husband? Who is he?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Who is he? Is this a guessing contest?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: What do you mean? (Rises - going L.C.)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: You're somebody's darling, an old man's darling, perhaps a nice lovely old man with millions!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Oh, don't you think you're smart?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: There's my reason. (Shows card he has taken from bouquet)

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: It isn't so! I don't know who wrote this, and you're just horrid to believe it!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I've got to believe my eyes.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: You believe your eyes before you believe me? Then I've found you out in time. You never loved me--and--don't you dare to ever speak to me again!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Good-bye, forever!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Good-bye, forever! (Neither moves)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I heard what you said.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Oh, did you? Well, this time it is goodbye forever! And when I say forever I mean definitely! Goodbye! (Looks at Alan, exits into house.)

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: What did Mary do to you, Alan?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: She didn't do anything to me, but she loves somebody else. I'm going to take my part of the fortune Uncle Barnaby is keeping for us, and go far far away!

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: I'll get my money from him too, and I'll go with you.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: I don't know, don't you?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Let's get a map and stick a pin in it, and whever the pin sticks, we'll go!

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: I've got a pin. (Producing one)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I have one too. (Produces another)

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: What is this--why--?

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: We're glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: And we want our money.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Ghosts, they can't be alive, ghosts!! Take them away!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Will you pay us our money?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: No, no, you are dead. Go away! Ghosts!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: We'll show you how alive we are. Present arms! (He and Jane draw pins.) Attack! (They start after Barnaby with pins and he runs in terror and exits)

div.stage: (As they chase him off BLACK OUT)
(As in original or Alan & Jane remain on as Barnaby rushes off)

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: We almost stuck him for the money. Are you still going to travel?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Yes. Although we'll be homeless rovers on the highway.

lg.l: And no parking space any place have we found.
And where is the nest - we can rest for the night?
But it's all right wherever we're bound

div.stage: (LIGHTS DIMMER DOWN on them and Change to Scene II)

div.head:
ACT I:
SCENE II: Garden well (Alex or Etc.)

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: Was that the widow Piper who slammed the door in our faces?

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Yes, it was. Thanks to that gypsy, what was her name gypsy --?

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: Gypsy Rose Lee.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: No, no, she was a gypsy Fawn. Not a gypsy Bear (bare).

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: Have you brought our pay?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Pay? You haven't earned it yet. Jane and Alan have returned.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Alive?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Painfully so!

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: They suspect...

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Nothing. They think it was all an accident. While they still trust us we must try again to -to remove them.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: I've told them I bought a new country house while they were away, and you two must take them there tonight, but the road to it leads thru the Spider's Forest.
Business detains me in the village. In the depth of the forest you will accidentally lose the children.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: It's a deadly place. I've heard of it.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Alive with dangers--small chance the children will ever come out of it.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: But will we?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: I don't think so. (Gonzorgo and Roderigo, together)

sp.speaker: Gon. & Rod.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: I don't think so many dangers are there....that is, for you.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: But when we have carried out the designs, we expect to be paid in cash.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: Yes, it's strictly a cash and carry proposition.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Don't worry about the money, I'll fetch the children here, and remember everything is on the q.t.

lg.l: On the Q.T. On the Q.T.
If we get our dough- re- mi--
Ray me fa so la si do!

div.stage: (BOY BLUE looks cautiously over the garden well.)

sp.speaker: Boy Blue
sp.p: Come on, the lawn is empty. (BO PEEP looks over the wall)

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: Hurry up Mary, now's your chance!!

sp.speaker: Boy Blue
sp.p: Do you know where you're going?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: As far from old Barnaby as I can get. And if I never come back, you can have my Shirley Temple doll.

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: Oh, don't talk that way!

div.stage: (Mary climbs down the wall assisted by the vine and boy BLUE and Bo Peep)

sp.speaker: Boy Blue
sp.p: Careful -slowly--there you are!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Hand down my baggage, please.
Goodbye! Goodbye!

sp.speaker: Boy Blue and Bo Peep
sp.p: Goodbye!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Boy Blue, you won't forget to feed the guinea pigs?

sp.speaker: Boy Blue
sp.p: I promise!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Goodbye! And don't forget to give some little pieces of cheese to my little mice, Mickey and Minnie. And take care of my Donald Duck. (starts to go. Rushes back again) Oh...oh...I forgot!

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: My overshoes! (They hand the overshoes to her. MARY EXITS L. to general chorus of goodbyes)

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: Tom Tom and Mary gone in one day! Mother will be pleased!

sp.speaker: Simon
sp.p: There she is, coming in the front way with the children.

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: Not a word! (After "not a word")

sp.speaker: Simon
sp.p: Here comes somebody! (All start to dodge down.) (Bo Peep stays)

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: Oh, it's only Jane!

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Only me. Where are the rest of the children?

sp.speaker: Boy Blue
sp.p: Getting ready for school.

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: I just despise it. Why, I'd rather get married than to go to school. (Leaves wall)

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Where are you all now?

sp.speaker: Simon
sp.p: Still in the primary. It's the nasty arithmetic that's keeping us back. Look at those sums we've got for today. (Drops book to Jane) Where the leaf is turned down.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Oh, these are easy.

sp.speaker: Red Riding Hood
sp.p: Come on boys and girls, Jane is going to do our sums for us!
sp.stage: (Sits on wall other Piper children do the same)
sp.p: I can't do that sum!

div.stage:
SONG NO. 7. or 7-a.
"I CAN'T DO THAT SUM". Jane and Ensemble. Children.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Now, Alan, my boy, you're going to my new home with Jane-- (ENTER GONZORGO AND RODERIGO L) --and these friends of mine.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Here's Jane, I'll tell her. (JANE RE-ENTERS R) Jane, we're going to Uncle Barnaby's new home!

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Where is it?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: A little journey, and these fellows are to take us. (Indicates Gon. and Rod.)

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: They'll see you safely there, and I'll follow.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: We're ready. And tomorrow I want my share of my fortune!

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Me, too!

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: We'll tend to that when you see me in the morning.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: If those men had long beards--

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I know. You'd think they were the villains who lured us on the boat.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: It wasn't us. I wouldn't harm a hair in anyone's head -- not even Joe Louis'.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: And I have an alibi. See my laywers, O'Brien, O'Rafferty, O'Reilly, and O'Cohen. (THEY take Jane and Alan's arms, Jane and Alan together)

sp.speaker: Jane & Alan
sp.p: Good-bye! Goodbye!

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: And you will never see me again. Goodbye. Goodbye. Forever!

div.head: SCENE III Spider's Forest.
div.stage: Specialty with Animal number. To open scene, (Possibly the kitchen pirates)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Rest here. This is a good place. (Leading her to mouth of Bear's den)

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: There's a spider's web.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: With a white moth in it.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Poor thing! -as badly tangled up in that web as we are in these woods! Do set it free. (Alan releases the moth)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: There it goes, flying for dear life. (Looking about) I wish we could fly too!

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: I wish we could, for I can't walk!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Then we'll rest a while. (Sits beside Jane) Try to sleep a bit.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: I'm too frightened.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Frightened! Ha, ha! What's that?

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: I don't know. (Pointing off) What's that?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Nothing at all. Don't worry I'm here to protect you! Come, let's go over here and take a little nap.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Yes, I'm so, so tired!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Yes, yes, we'll take a little sleep.
Sleep, sleep...a little peaceful sleep.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Goodnight!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Goodnight!

stage.hi: BUTTERFLY BALLET: END OF ACT I.

div.head:
BABES IN TOYLAND
ACT II
-----
ACT II:
SCENE: The Christmas Tree Grove in Toyland.
div.stage: (At the end of the number Barnaby and Widow Piper enter from arch up L.C. HILDA from down R)

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Mary's in Toyland, I'm sure of that, and we'll not go home again till we find her.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: A fine dance she has lead us for three weeks!

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: A love-chase for me.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Never mind, we'll make her Mrs. Barnaby yet.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: With the aid of Isnpector Marmaduke!

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: Who's he?

div.stage: (MARMADUKE enters from arch, unseen by others)

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: The leading detective of Toyland.

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: You have sent for Marmaduke and he is here!

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Can you find Contrary Mary?

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: You have sent for me because you cannot find her yourself!

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: He's a regular mind-reader!

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Do you think you can run her down?

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: A well-bred detective never runs a lady down.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Mary was the apple of my eye. She has lips like cherries and cheeks like peaches.

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: (Writing in note-book) Wanted--a female with a face like a fruit store. Would you like to take her dead or alive?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Alive for choice. She's to be my wife, you know.

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: Must she marry you?

sp.speaker: Barnaby & Widow
sp.p: She must!

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: (Going L.) And does she know it?

sp.speaker: Barnaby & Widow
sp.p: She does.

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: We'll begin with looking in the river.

div.stage: (Exit down L. with Widow and Barnaby)

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Ah, Hilda!

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: Tom Tom! (They embrace) My, but your Ma's mad at you and Mary!

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Where is mother? Not here in Toyland?

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: Here with your brothers and sisters and old Barnaby.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Don't say you've seen me.

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: Never fear.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: I'm employed as Court Crier to the Court Royal, and Mary is a doll's dressmaker at the Master Toymaker's workshop, under the name of Mlle. Elisette.

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: Who's the Master Toymaker?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: A great person here. He sets the fashion in dolls and toys for all the world.

sp.speaker: Hilda
sp.p: Barnaby has just engaged Inspector Marmaduke to hunt for Mary.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Follow me, we'll go to her and warn her! (BOTH EXEUNT up L.)

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: Strangers! Where did you come from?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: We know where we come from, but we don't where we've got to. We were lost in a forest at our home, and after many adventures, reached a strange sea coast. A passing vessel brought us here, and we don't care how soon another takes us away.

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: This is Toyland.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Toyland? Were you made in Germany or Connecticut?

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: (Indignantly) I'm not a dummy. I'm a detective.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: What's the difference?

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: Do you know Contrary Mary, I'm looking for her? (JAKE & ALAN nod) Tell me what she wore the last time you saw her.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: A blue and white polka-dot dress.

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: Ah, a clue!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: You'll be sure to find her now.

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: A polka-dot dress is always spotted.

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: Bah!

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: If I could only find Tom Tom, I wouldn't care.
Do you know Tom Tom?

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: Is it anything like Contract?

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: No, he's a young man - very very handsome...and he has the grandest eyes and teeth and the most sensitive ears --

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: I'm not in the least interested.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Of course everybody doesn't call him Tom Tom.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: No, especially those who don't know him.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: His family name was Piper, so to strangers he is Mr. Piper, but he is very very handsome, and he has the grandest eyes and teeth, and the most sensitive ears.

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: But I haven't sensitive ears. (Rushes off under arch.)

div.stage: (GIRLS BEGIN TO ENTER DURING preceding speech)

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Wait, I want to tell you more about Tom Tom.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: My dear, what fine looking things the parade has brought to town!

sp.speaker: 2nd Girl
sp.p: What perfect frights, they must have fallen out of the moon.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: Tell us where you came from?

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: First, I want to find out something about the place I am in! Pardon me while I go sight seeing! (EXITS down R)

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: And who are you?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I'm nothing yet, but when I grow up, I want to be a radio star.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: What could you do on the radio?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I could be Uncle Don Crosby. That's something new, isn't it? Giving advice to the children in song form.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: You mean a sort of lullaby?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Yes, just what!

div.stage:
SONG
ALAN AND CHORUS:
"ROCK A BYE BABY"
(PIPER CHILDREN ENTER from L. side of stage, they are playfully pulling the master toymaker after them, each child drags or carries on a toy. Possible dance here with BABY DOLLS...or a cakewalk)

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: There! There! You have me quite out of breath, my dears. I must rest a moment.

div.stage: (Sits on large toy block, which two of the children place C. for him)

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: When we find Mother, she'll pay you for these lovely play- things.

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: There's nothing to pay. I am the world's master toymaker and I want to give these toys to you. Just a little rememberance in the heart of a child is more to me than anything else in the world.

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: Haven't you any little boys and girls of your own?

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: No. That's why I'm free to love all children, and to try and make them love me.

sp.speaker: Red Hiding Hood
sp.p: Do you make toys that talk?

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: Aye, talk and walk and do everything but think. I can give them everything but a soul, and some day I may give them even that.
sp.stage: (He reads the underlined phrase, so tragically, that all the children shrink from him. Noticing their notion he immediately returns to his amiable manner)
sp.p: But I must go. I have work to do.
Come to my work-shop, and see all the other toys that I have there.
sp.stage: (EXITS down L. ENTER WIDOW from arch)

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Ah here are my angels!

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: See what the Master Toymaker has given us. (Children show toys, BARNABY enters up L., holding TOMTOM by the wrist)

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Here's Tom-Tom. Just caught him in the crowd. (Cries of "Hello Tom Tom", "Hello, brother", from the children)

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Naughty boy, where's your sister?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: I don't know. I don't know anything about her.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Tell the truth, you rascal! You ran away together.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: No, we didn't. I don't know where Mary is at all!

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Come, all of you, look for her. Scatter and be quick about it! Tom tom, you go with us. (WIDOW EXITS quickly with TOM TOM)

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Hurry up! Find your sister! Be off with you!

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: Find her for you? Not much.

div.stage: (The children rush off stage; JILL remains on the stage playing with the doll the Toymaker gave her, BARNABY turns and sees JILL busy with doll, sitting on the stage down R)

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Jill, why don't you do as you're told? (Sneeringly) Precious Pet-mother's ownest! Just wait till I'M your brother-in-law!

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: I could faint with joy at the prospect!

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Badness, where do you expect to go when you die?

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: If it's any place where you ain't, I'll be happy.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: (Furiously) If you were only mine! How I could box your ears! if you were only mine!

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: It's hopeless! I can never be yours! (Barnaby seizes Jill's doll, strikes it, then kicks it about the stage) Help! Help! A lady's being struck -give me my doll!

div.stage: (GRUMIO ENTERS at top of runway over arch. Hears Jill's cries, stumbles and rolls down runway to stage)

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: (Picking up doll and facing Barnaby) Hold! How dare you strike a helpless female in the face!

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Bless you! You have saved my child! (Faints in Grumio's arms)

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: You'll hear from me later. (EXITS angrily under arch)

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: (Calling after him) Yes, do write, even if it's just a post-card. Courage, beautiful stranger--your child has only lost an ear.

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: My name is Jill. What's yours?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: Grumio. I'm the Master Toymaker's apprentice. What do you do?

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Oh, I live a life of leisure, but I'm going to leave society and go to work. Perhaps I'll even be on relief.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: I had trouble at home too. Mother kept a butler, who objected to my wearing his evening clothes.

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: But didn't you ever have any other ambitions?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: Yes, I wanted to be a politician. It's the only business where you can sit down and run at the same time!

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Is there any chance of landing a job here.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: Come to my master's workshop. They're shorthanded there and I can get you a place.

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Can you fix my doll there?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: (Holding doll so sawdust pours out) Yes, better hurry up, she may have a sawdust hemmorhage.

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: What'll you charge?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: My charge will be just one kiss.

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: All right, you send the bill to mother.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: But after I've seen mother's face, I may not want to collect it. Give me one kiss and I'll be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: You won't give me one kiss.

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Yes, but you won't be satisified.

div.stage: (He is just about to kiss her, but enter the WIDOW and Barnaby.)

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Brute!
sp.stage: (Leads Jill down stage grasping her by the ear, and Barnaby chases Grumio off stage thru arch.)
sp.p: You're too young to be kissing strangers!

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: I just wanted to find out what a kiss was.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: A kiss is nothing divided by two.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: You got that kissing idea from the movies...from now on you'll see nothing but travelogues.

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: (Enters with MAN reading document.) You may report to me in the toyshop, in an hour!

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: (To Toymaker) You're the King-pin of all the toymakers, I've heard. I'd like to hire you to make a few toys for me.

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: Ah, then you love the children too?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Oh, I simply dote on them!

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: What would you like me to make for them?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: A lot of dangerous toys. Toys that a child would eagerly accept. That would destroy them, and even kill them, in some clever way. (JANE ENTERS under arch, overhears)

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: Why do you hate the children so bitterly?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: My late sister left her two vicious bad-tempered children Alan and Jane for me to look after. What a life they've led me! Even their fortune, which will be mine in another week, could hardly repay me for the trouble they have caused me.

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: Are they dead?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Yes, they were lost in the forest, I've seen the last of them!
A thousand dollars, if you'll take the order. Twelve hundred! Fifteen hundred!

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: No, no!

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Eighteen hundred!

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: No, no, don't tempt me. Eighteen hundred dollars for toys, that would kill and destroy!

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: I'll make it two thousand dollars! Just let me see you alone in your work shop, and we'll close the bargain. (BOTH EXEUNT L)

div.stage: (JANE and ALAN enter under arch much excited)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: And if we're not home in a week, Uncle Barnaby gets our fortune!

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Yes, that's what I heard him say!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Now I understand Uncle Barnaby now I know him. He's as easy to see thru as a cellophane wrapper.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: I'm sure he had us lost in the woods.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: And lost at sea the same way. Oh, he's been playing a losing game with every way.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: We must get home--we haven't a penny, what's to be done?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Or, who's to be done?

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: First let us change these clothes. Nobody else in Toyland dresses like this, and Uncle Barnaby will surely hear about us.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: That's a risk we can't afford. We must shift our wardrobe, but how?

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Can it be? Alan and Jane!

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Jill!

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: And a runaway just like you two!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I hope you've run away with a tailor!

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Or a dressmaker.

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Neither, but I've just been engaged to dress the dolls at the Master Toymaker's.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Do you think you could find anything there to fit us? We don't want to be captured.

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Perhaps, some of the Toymaker's dolls are nearly as big as you.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Follow me! (The three exeunt under arch)

div.stage: (BO PEEP & BOY BLUE ENTER UNDER ARCH)

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: I wonder what's become of MAry?

sp.speaker: Boy Blue
sp.p: Maybe she's married a title, and has had to go to work to support him.

div.stage: (MARY ENTERS under arch with small milliner's box under arm)

sp.speaker: Bo Peep, Boy Blue etc.
sp.p: It's Mary!

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: What in the world are you doing in Toyland? (MARMADUKE ENTERS under arch)

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Oh, I'm making dolls for the master Toymaker! and my alias is Mam'sell Elisette.

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: Hold in the name of the law! Stand up where you are! Hold, I say!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.stage: (Ignoring Marmaduke, coming down with the group)
sp.p: I want to hear all the news from home. Are all the guinea pigs well, and how is the new donkey?

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: I am here!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: But you're not the one I was speaking of.

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: Listen to me for a moment! Do any of you know a girl named Mary? Don't answer if it may incriminate you.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: I am the world's most famous inspector!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: What of boilers?

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: No, of the police! Describe Contrary Mary to me.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: She has long bobbed hair, a lovely speaking voice, but very loud. And she cries so much her cheeks are streamlined.

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: (Taking notes) Complexion?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Fair. Just fair, and I believe at that I'm exaggerating.

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: How was she dressed when you saw her last?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: She was wearing a white fish net over black satin.... the satin was white at one time. The neck line was high with a Freddie Bartholomew collar...The back was low, sweet and lo, - there were little cream puff sleeves... with blue ribbon on the side...

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: I don't believe --

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: The dress was straight to the knees, where it was gored by 8 champagne inserts to give it a waltz swing...a sort of Champagne Waltz!

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: I don't believe I'm getting anywhere....but I am getting anywhere--anywhere away from you! (Dashes off under arch)

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: Well, you certainly tired him out!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: You don't know how glad I am to see you all, but I wish Tom Tom were here....

sp.speaker: Boy Blue
sp.p: And what about Alan? Don't you miss him?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Of course I do. Oh, if you only knew how heavy my heart is.

div.stage: (GRUMIO enters from arch, carrying the head of a toy captain)

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: The toy captain is busted, and now the parade is spoiled.

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: What's the matter, Grumio?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: (Pointing to head) I'll be put in jail for this. This was the wooden soldier that was to head the wooden regiment he presents to the City today... I had charge on him, and when I went to wind him up, I found someone had stolen his clothes. Let me find out who did it! That's all!

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Twas I Grumio! (Falls on knees)

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Strike and avenge yourself! I took the clothes to help two old friends...

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: Ah! To help old friends you ruin me! Be gone, female, and leave me to the sorrow you have brought upon me! (Throws her to the ground and steps over her)

div.stage: (JANE & ALAN enter in the doll costumes and exchange surprised glances and military salutes with the other two)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: (Aside to Jane) Looks like a bottle of Chili sauce. (Aloud) Who are you?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: The Toymaker's apprentice, who is responsible for the toys that you have broken. (Points to wooden captain's broken head)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: The wooden captain? (To Jill) The toy I broke when I took these clothes off of him!

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: The same. It's time for the parade, but I can't start without the wooden captain.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Well, I can't do without his clothes.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: (With sudden inspiration) Then by the way of paying for them, you might lead the parade yourself.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: What - me?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: That will get me out of the trouble that you have got me into. Do you think you could act like a toy soldier?

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Of course -- just be yourself.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Jane, I'll lead the parade, and you can look for Tom Tom.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: I'm sure Tom Tom isn't here.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: One word more, my one cylinder brained friend! If I get you out of this trouble, will you help us to get out of the country?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: Come to the work shop after the parade, and I'll arrange it!

sp.speaker: Jane and Alan
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: Leave that to me! Just join the wooden grenadiers, they're ready to march!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Come on, we're off! (Exeunt up Left)

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Oh, the parade must have started.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: Come with me and I'll get you a seat in the reviewing stand!

div.stage:
(Big number and dance and black cut and change to Street scene.)
------------

div.head:
ACT II:
SCENE II STREET SCENE:

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: It's a cold world, Gonzorgo; unless something turns up, I shall worry myself into a stew.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Worry yourself into two stews if possible- one for me!

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: Is it true what the gypsy said, are you married now?

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: No, my wife passed away a year ago. The light of my life has gone, but I'd like to strike another match!

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: And here comes a possible flame! It's the Widow Piper.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: My woodland fllower!--

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: Why do you call her a woodland flower?

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: She'll grow wild, if someone doesn't cultivate her!

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Have you seen anything of a young lady who answers to the name of Mary?

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: You--Bernice?

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Infatuated girl, why have you followed me here?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Oh, Master Barnaby's friends!

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: Fate has mixed us up again.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Have you forgotten what Floretta, the Fawn of the Forest told me? You are married!

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: 'Tis false, you are the only girl I ever loved. Don't seek further for a husband!

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Find my daughter Mary for me and I shall consider it!

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: What is she like?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: She's only 15, very pretty, and very brainy. Here's a description of her written on this paper. Find her and you may be lucky! (EXITS)

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: If you were a young girl very pretty and very brainy, what would you do?

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: I'd enter a beauty contest.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: No, I said brainy. Brains! But if she is going to marry old Barnaby, you could use her for a blue print to make an idiot!

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: Yes, old Barnaby is 45, and she's only 15. He's three times as old.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Yes and in five years he'll be fifty and she'll be 20, then he'll only be two and a half times as old.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: Yes and in 15 years he'll be sixty and she'll be thirty then he'll only be twice as old!

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: How long will she have to wait before they become the same age?

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: The paper says she left with someone else. It reads, "The missing twain". Say, what does twain mean?

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Twain, it means two!

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Two -two! Twain!

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: You're too old to be talking baby talk!

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: My dear Watson, this is a very baffling case.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: Don't you know a good solution?

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Yes, boracic acid, that's a good solution. Now the girl has been stolen by some desperate criminial, now let's both concentrate. Who is the worst criminal you know?

sp.speaker: Rod. & Gon.
sp.p: You!!

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: (ENTERS) Hold! I'm searching for Contrary Mary! Taking you at your face value, you're both under arrest!

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: You can't arrest us, we've just been appointed detectives. I appointed him.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: And I appointed him!

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: I will now give you the third degree!

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Oh good, we're going to join a lodge!

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: Have you ever committed any crimes?

sp.speaker: Rod. & Gon.
sp.p: No! We swear it by our right hands.

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: This is truth serum wine! The liquid lie detector, quaff of it and you will tell the truth.
You drink!

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: I'm as honest as (Drinks) --as the best bank robber and confidence man. How I laughed when I sold people shares in a Hidden Treasure....

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: And you, you drink!

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: You doubt my honor.
Wow! I am the king of larceny and arsony. And crooked slot machines!

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: Two very desperate cases! What was your most serious crime?

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: I worked for the EUREKA GET RICH QUICK COMPANY. I sold lottery tickets!

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: And I sold Stock for the Wild Cat gold mine. I worked for the Eureka, Get Rich Quick company.

sp.speaker: Marmaduke
sp.p: You are master criminals! (Takes bottle) Here's to crime! (Takes drink) ...I was THE EUREKA GET RICH QUICK COMPANY!

div.stage:
(Or exit of Marmaduke, and DANCE SPECIALTY FOR Gon. and Rod.)
BLACK OUT:
