div.head: SCENE III The Master Toymaker's toyshop.
div.stage:
WORKMEN discovered:
TOM TOM enters from door L.C.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Thanks to that friendly vine next to my prison windows, I am free! (Turns to workman.) I have a summons for the Master Toymaker from the court Royal!

sp.speaker: Workman
sp.p: You'll find him inside.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: But I do not know him what does he look like?

sp.speaker: Workman
sp.p: You don't know the master toymaker? You must be a new-comer in Toyland!

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: I am. But my father came here when I was a lad, and many times he talked about it.

sp.speaker: Workman
sp.p: There is much to talk about here!

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: I remember he had many fond memories of Toyland!

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: Well, what can I do for you? Looking for a pretty toy?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Sir! Do I look as though I came from the nursery? (Hands Toymaker document) A summons from the Court Royal to the master Toymaker.

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: (Looking at paper) Ah, yes. Say to the Prefect I'll be on hand at the appointed time. Now, run along, little boy! (TOM TOM EXITS L.C.) Max, the bill for the toys we shipped today.

sp.speaker: Max
sp.p: The consignment is ready, sir!

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: Put the goods on board at once! The captain sends word he sails immediately.

div.stage: (MAX and Workman exit R. and L.C.)

(Toymaker left on stage. Bus. Places paper on the mantel-piece and goes back to the table, watches the last character off R. Hurriedly closes door, returns to table, pours contents from phial into large flask with left hand; leaving right hand free to work switch after exhibition of sparks.)

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: Grumio!

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: (Entering) Yes, sir!

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: The secret I have sought for years still mocks me. A thousand times have I sought to find the element that makes the charm complete. Within this crystal glass, there dwells a score of demon spirits drawn by spells and incantations. There, there, is the charm that will give me dominion over the souls of evil! That I may bid them enter the toys and mannikins.
sp.stage: (Works flask again, JILL enters right during his motion)

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: This has nothing to do with toy making I'm sure! I must find out the secret! (Conceals herself, in cabinet up R.)

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: Come in! (GRUMIO ENTERS L.C. FOLLOWED BY TWO MEN. One carries wine cask, the other a table with cheese, cookies, etc.)

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: Here's a cask of wine sent you by an old gentleman named Barnaby!

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: (Rising, going right) Put it down, I'm in no mood for it right now! (EXITS R.) (MEN places articles and exeunt)

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: I can never do anything right! (Takes cookie) I'm bewitched like the place. They say it's haunted! It does seem horrible, Maybe a little drink will steady my nerves! (Taps the wine cask and takes a drink) This place isn't half bad at that! (Takes 2nd drink) No, sir, this place is all right! (Candle drops) Ghosts! Spirits! I'd better get some spirits to fight this! (Other business follows, causing additional fright) (JILL enters from cabinet) Am I seeing things?

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: I'm not a thing, you remember me, I'm Jill!

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: Oh, yes, two Jills make one pint, two pints make on drunk, ...

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: You're intoxicated.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: Don't talk like that, girls!

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Girls?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: My mistake, I've had a couple of drinks.

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Two drinks, and I'm girls! If you had 5 drinks I'd be quintuplets!

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: You don't like me, do you?

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: In spite of your faults, I think you're the tops!

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: I must be the top, my head is still spinning. But come, my Princess, it is gay tonight in Vienna - there is music, wine and waltzing. Will you waltz with me?

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: No - but if you'll come out of Vienna - I might dance with you.

div.stage: (DANCING SPECIALTY, or THEY Waltz to an exit)

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: What's this? Men, clear away the ruin. The scamp has been at the wine! (Examines articles on the table, as if they have been damaged. MEN exit after clearing stage.) (BARNABY looks in at L.C.)

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Here I am according to appointment. (Coming down) Have you thought over my offer?

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: For toys that will maim and injure children?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Something tells me you would put your whole heart into the work.

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: (Sneeringly) Your liberality would call for that much interest.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Your final answer?

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: (Taking him Center) What would you say to a doll with the spirit of a fiend controlling it? Would it not be a dainty gift for a child one dislikes?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: A doll with the soul of a demon, a master thought!

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: Come back in the twilight, in the interval I'll experiment again. (Indicates table left)

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: I pray for your success. (EXITS L.C.)

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: Aha! You scoundrel, you drank my wine, didn't you?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: No, sir, I was just testing it for you! The captain of the ship wants to see you on board at once!

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: (Impatiently) What about?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: It's something about the cargo you're sending.

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: Very well! And when I return call my attention to the fact that you are to be discharged. (EXITS.)

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: Yes, sir. (Going quickly to door R.) Bring the wrappings, Jill! You men bring these crates! .....Alan and Jane will travel in style!... (Men bring in 2 packing boxes, exeunt) (ALAN & JANE ENTER L.C.)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: How about us? How are you going to get us out of the country, your ship sails in an hour.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: You go as freight.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: You mean as dolls?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: You'll be taken on board the ship, that's bound for your country in those. (Indicting crates)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Be sure we're marked fragile, this side up!

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: And I hope I'm sent F.O.B. Free of bumps!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Jane, take care of yourself!

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: So far, so good!

div.stage: (MARY enters just before Grumio can get down into crate)

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Grumio, I want you to run out and match this sample.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: It's Mary!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Quickly, please, four yards. Bring it back at once.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: (Going reluctantly) That doll's all right. (Points to Alan) You needn't bother about him, Mam'selle.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Hurry! Hurry! (Grumio exits L.C.) (Mary looks at Alan, starts violently) Only a wooden dummy with no sense and yet he reminds me so much of Alan! (Turns right)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: In this game I am the dummy!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Poor boy, it's very like him. I could almost imagine we were alone together. If he's meant for an officer, he needs something to show his rank. (Goes to work table and gets properties)
Shall I sew them on? No, it would be quicker and safer to nail them on his chest.
sp.stage: (Looks on table for tacks and hammer)
sp.p: I might nail on a few yards of fresh gold braid while it's on my mind.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Your mind, oh, don't mind me!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: This will do, and this- (Tries medals on Alan's coat) Dear, dear, but you are like Alan! (Angrily) I wish you were, that's all! To believe that I'd forget you for such a creature as Barnaby! Will I ever see you again? Oh Alan where are you now, I wonder! (Turns away)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: So, you're wondering too!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Will you ever come back and say "Mary I'm dreadfully sorry I was all wrong?" And you know what I would do, I would embrace you, Alan! (Embracesm him)

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Why, what is the matter with this machine? It must be out of order! (tries to break away)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Mary!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: It is you, Alan, after all!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: And now you say something like I'll forgive you Alan.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: I do, I do!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: And I'll say Mary I was dreadfully sorry, I was all wrong. Because you knew all the time...

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Yes, I knew all the time that you loved me.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Oh, Mary! (Puts arms around her.)

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: But Alan, you in this costume,--what does it mean?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: It means that Grumio is going to ship us home as dolls on a boat that sails in an hour or two!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: In that case, where is Jane?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: In that case!

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: (ENTERS L.C. Alan resumes a toy attitude) Getting that toy ready for shipment?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: Something wrong with his machinery. (ALAN moves his hand automatically) I'll attend to that before he goes to Siberia.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Sibera!

div.stage: (MAN enters with marking pot and brush, used for marking packing cases)

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Oh, he doesn't go to Siberia, he's billed to--to--

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: (To working man) Cross out the address on those crates, and write these. (Handing workman also a slip of paper) Send that to his Majesty, the Sultan of Beejumbo! It's going to be a surprise for the Sultan's harem!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Ah, a harem!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Pardon me, sir, but aren't you getting them mixed? (Points to Alan)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Oh no, he isn't getting them mixed.

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: So I am. It's the Dutch Doll that goes to the Sultan. (Points to Jane's crate, and workman paints new address on it)

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: This one is broken.

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: There's time to fix him. He goes by caravan tomorrow. He's bound for Kalamazooskie, Eastern Siberia.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Kalamazooskie sounds like a long way from home.

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: His uniform needs something.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: If I'm going to Siberia, I need an overcoat.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: But he can't be fixed inside of a week, and the Dutch Doll isn't all right, either. (Points to Jane's crate)

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: What's the matter with her?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: She needs a new face.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I'm glad Jane can't hear that.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: You can't send those wax faces to hot countries. They melt. She ought to have a wooden head like this. (Raps Alan's head) (Bus. Alan)

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: Oh I'll take the risk of sending that doll to Beejumbo.
Put that box on the ship that sails for the far East.
And as for that doll,
Within the hour, Max shall have his works spread upon the table!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: He's not going to give me the works!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Here's a dreadful fix, how is Jane going to get out of it?
What's that?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: That's Jane always crashing in some place where she's not wanted.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: We must help her. I'll run and see what I can do! (EXITS L.C.)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I'll find Grumio. Where are you Grumio, Grumio, Grumio? (Door L.3. opens, ALAN assumes toy pose, TOYMAKER enters L.3., goes to table, turns and looks towards flask)

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: Now once more to seek the missing element! It will give me dominion over the souls of evil! (Works switch, the glow appears) The light! The light! Can it be at last success!! (Turns to flash again and cries in ecstasy) I triumph! I triumph!! (Smokes appears.) The spirits of evil I bid you enter the forms I have fashioned in human shape! (TOY figures move on stage) It is true at last I have found the spell at last. They turn to me, their master! Fiends, all the fiends! (Turns to Alan) Speak, speak, you live!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Undo your work, before it is too late!

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: There is gratitude, I give you human form, I take you from the gloom, and you reproach me!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Take care, these things have only murder in their hearts.

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: I do not fear them.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Look there! (Pointing to doll who approaches Toymaker with knife)

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: (Turning quickly) Ah! (Doll retreats. A murmur of defiance from the others. He shows terror) Obey, or else I'll send your souls back to the abyss from which I brought them.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: You've lost. You gave them life to hate and slay and kill. And you will be their first victim!

sp.speaker: Toymaker
sp.p: No! No! No!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Your commands are vain! (Dolls advance to attack Toymaker.)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Stop, stop, I say!

div.stage: (The dolls kill the Toymaker and escape)
(Alan left with the Toymaker, tries to revive him)
(Barnaby enters, and accuses Alan of killing Toymaker)

(THEY carry the Toymaker off at signal from Barnaby. Left alone, Barnaby shows his delight at his success of schemes against Alan. The dolls appear armed with clubs, broomsticks etc. and they fall upon Barnaby, and gives him a sound beating, he howls for mercy, (see score) - on the curtain falls)

div.head:
BABES IN TOYLAND
ACT III
------
div.stage:
ACT III
SCENE: Court yard of the palace of Justice.

Opening March.
Tom Tom, Piper children, lady and male advocates. Populace on stage at opening. March of Court officials.

sp.speaker: Tom Tom
sp.p: Hear ye! Hear ye! If one Master Alan be among ye, he is for the last time summoned to appear before the Court Royal to say why he shall not be condemned to die!

sp.speaker: Bo-Peep
sp.p: What has Master Alan done?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: He is said to have slain the Master Toymaker. After his arrest he escaped.

sp.speaker: Boy Blue
sp.p: Was he alone guilty?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Many believe the Toymaker was killed by a band of strange beings who were seen rushing from the shop. The police can find no trace of them.

div.stage: (Chorus exits to repeat of March. TOM TOM joins children)

sp.speaker: Bo Peep
sp.p: Oh, Tom Tom, how did Alan get himself in such a scrape?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: I don't know. But it's very serious.

sp.speaker: Riding Hood
sp.p: Can we do anything to help him?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Help him in his flight, if you meet him. (ENTER JANE)

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Tom Tom!

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Jane! where in the world have you been?

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: All over looking for you.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: And I've been doing the same! What a lucky day!

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: For us, but not for Alan.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Poor fellow, he is in trouble. Any news of him?

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: None. Contrary Mary is with him and they're trying to get out of Toyland together!

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Without passports that will be hard to do.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Who accuses him of the Toymaker's death?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Only your uncle Barnaby!

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: The wicked old man! He's taken our money, now he wants our lives!

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: The Toymaker was the King's favorite subject. He has ordered the Court Royal to convict him without a hearing. But I must go. The Court is in session!

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: I will await you at the courthouse. You won't be long?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: I'll count the minutes til I'm with you. I'm so glad I have you again. (Jane throws a kiss to him and exits.)

div.stage:
SONG NO. Tom.
"MY CASTLE IN SPAIN"
(After song ALAN, GRUMIO, JILL and MARY enter up R. ALAN is in comedy disguise, whiskers etc)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: So far all right, nobody recognizes my disguise.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: You can't blame them.

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: You don't look a bit like the police description.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: No-one ever does.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Now for the last obstacle, the passports.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.p: There's the office, but the passport clerk is busy. You'll have to wait a few minutes.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Remember both of you, if anybody questions you about us, you're to be dumb!

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: We'll just be our own natural selves. (Joins Grumio, they exeunt left) (UNCLE BARNABY ENTERS unseen at back left, recognizes Mary and Alan)

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: If we get safely out of Toyland, where shall we go? (Barnaby exits R. at back)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: To our home first. Then we'll get married and go abroad.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: To a far away country that Jane and I visited after our shipwreck.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Is the country you're talking about a nice one for -- for young married people?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: When young people marry they go to a place that's usually called Maple Heights. Because it's surrounded by willow trees.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Willow trees? We could plant a bed of onions right next to them and have weeping willows.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: It's called the heights because it's on a prairie.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: I know the place, the renting agents says it's five minutes from the station... that is if you travel by aeroplace.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Then a kind business man builds them a semi-colonial cottage on weekly payments. And after you've been married forty years then the Bond and Mortgage company takes it over.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: And I suppose they fall in love just as we do, and they exchange all sorts of beautiful vows.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Before marriage?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: And after?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: It's quite the same as here and everywhere else.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: So you're keeping a budget? All I brought in the last year was one necktie. You have ordered 14 dresses, four pairs of shoes, one squirrel coat, without consulting ne.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Well, I have to wear them don't I?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Yes but I have to pay for them, don't I?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: No, you don't. I haven't asked you for a single cent for a whole year. I have had everything charged.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: How many times have I asked you not to read the newspaper at the breakfast table!?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: What else is there around here interesting?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: You never dared speak to me like that before we were married.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Well, before we were married you never came down to breakfast looking the way you do!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Mother always said you were a brute. Oh, why did I ever marry you?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: So you're beginning to wonder too?

div.stage: (Lights down. Then Alan and girl discovered at right of stage)

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: So your wife is always quarrelling with you?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Yes, every time I go out, she accuses me playing cards with my friends.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: It was nice of you to take your secretary out, have a few cocktails and then go dancing...but how will you explain it to your wife?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: There's only one way out of it - and that is to tell her the truth! Goodnight!

div.stage: (LIGHTS OUT. Then Alan discovered at left with his wife)

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: And where have you been?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: My dear I'm going to tell you the truth. I wanted a little relaxation, so I took my secretary out and we had some cocktails, and then we went to a night club.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Don't you try to fool me. You've been playing cards again!

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: So Alan objects to being tried by a court of nine judges? And he petitions to ask for an appointment of fifteen. He doesn't realize it's unconstitutional.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Oh, it's you, is it?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: It's a fine morning for a wedding, Mistress Mary.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Whose wedding?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Ours. I'll be short and sweet with you, Mistress Mary! There's a marriage bureau next to the court-room-- (Points off) and we'll be married there at once, or...

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Or what?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: I'll hand Alan over! (Pointing L.) He's in there. I know his disguise. In a moment the Court Royal will condemn him for killing the Toymaker.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: You wouldn't betray him?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: It's my duty! He has disgraced the family. He's an assassin! But for your sweet sake I'll let him escape.
No, you won't warn him.
sp.stage: (GONZORGO and RODERIGO dressed as executioners, with brazier, ropes, pincers, enter from court-room with large legal document)
sp.p: What you have there?

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: A warrant to execute Alan, your scamp of a nephew!

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: You shall decide. Will you take his life, or my name?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Let me see that warrant! (Reading) Rack--hot irons--pincers for my Alan!
Is it is to save Alan, I'll agree. Take me to the marriage bureau!

div.stage: (Seizes Barnaby and rushes him off stage)
(ENTER JANE R. PIPER AND CHILDREN ON R. & L.)

sp.speaker: Miss Jane
sp.p: Why, when did you two start out as plumbers?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: We're not plumbers, we're executioners. We know nothing about the business, it was influence and this is a political appointment.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: You look like you belong to the Black legion!

sp.speaker: Rod
sp.p: We're amateurs at this rope business, but we'll soon get the hang of it!

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Has the court sent for you?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: It has. We shall shortly fill our first order.

div.stage: NOTE: (If you do not wish to do the song "We Won't Be Happy till he gets it". And you have no number to replace this, here is the lyrics of a song which could be set to music, and beginning with 3-8 dialogue would run:)

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: It will be Alan. But you will be cursed if you do anything to hurt him.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Cursed? Lady, we've been cursed by hard luck all our lives.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: You don't know what hard luck is. I think one of my ancestors must have been Calamity Jane!

stage.hi: "MEET ME ON THE HARD LUCK MOON".

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Oh, ever since I was a kid no matter what I said or did, You'd always find me in an awful boat,

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: And every photograph of me off in the background you would see Somebody always leading off my goat.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: I'm great big mister easy mark, and life for me has been no lark I'm quite unhappy, sad as I can be.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Good luck for me has been real slow, and I have had my share of woe, Just like an undertaker's jubilee.

lg.l: Meet me under the hard luck moon,
Where the blackbirds keep on singing,
We'll have a grand old kill-joy time,

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: It will be Alan. Boys and girls, this coward will kill Alan. Don't let him. (Pipers threaten Gonzorgo)

sp.speaker: Simon
sp.p: We won't. We will never let you live to do this.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Young man, don't you dare lay hands on an officer of the law!

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Prepare a chair for him. (Gonzorgo is placed on high chair) We are going to make it warm for you.

div.stage:
Song: NUMBER:
"HE WON'T BE HAPPY TILL HE GETS IT."
(With possible Specialty of Gon, Rod. and Jane.)
(Jane and Pipers with Chorus. All exit at the end of Number)

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Now, Mrs. Barnaby, we'll hear your sweetheart's sentence.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: I've just heard mine. (ENTER ALAN with crowd. Enter TOM TOM on stage of house)

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Hear ye! Hear ye! The Court Royal herewith finds the outlaw, Alan, guilty of the Master Toymaker's death and orders that he be executed in the manner prescribed by law, when found....

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: I'll do my duty as a good citizen and a relative as well. There is the criminal!

div.stage: (Tears whiskers from Alan's face. A general start and exclamation)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Who is this villain?

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Your unhappy uncle! Take him, he has disgraced me enough. Now, let the sentence be carried out.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Wait!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Yes, wait!
You give me back my whiskers!

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: I have not finished. He shall be executed in the manner prescribed by the law when found--unless he takes advantage of the law which gives every condemned man the right to plead the benefit of widow."

sp.speaker: Mary and Alan
sp.p: The benefit of widow?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: An ancient law of Toyland, meant to assist deserving class of subjects.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: What is the benefit of widow?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Any widow, may claim a condemned man for her second husband, and he shall be free as long as he supports said widow and saves her from becoming a charge upon the state.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: And may the victim choose the widow?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Some have preferred the gallows. Do you claim the benefit?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: No, I'll die rather than marry anybody but Contrary Mary.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: If you mean Mrs. Barnaby, you're a little bit late.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: You? Mrs. Barnaby?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Alan, he recognized you, but he swore to let you escape if I married him at once!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I'll plead that benefit. Bring on your widows. I'll marry and live!

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Let the court heralds summon the widows of our city.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Courage, somebody will surely choose you.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: It's so undignified. I feel like a prize at a grab bag party.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Don't despair, old man, some widow will surely find you worth taking.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: You needn't speak of him as though he were a marked down remnant.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: To think that we're parted forever!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Not forever. (Looking at Barnaby) The joyful day may soon arrive when they'll expect me to wear crape for that!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: A joyful day indeed! I'll ride with you in the first carriage, and on the way to the cemetary I'll propose to you!

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Then here's where I give up smoking and go in for physical culture. As soon as I've engaged places on the coach, my dear, we'll depart upon our honeymoon. (EXITS L. chuckling) Remember, the sentence will be carried out if a widow does not choose you in fifteen minutes.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Don't worry. I'm liable to be killed in the rush! (EXIT CHORUS)

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: I'll hurry them along. (EXITS UP R)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: All right. Tell the widows I'm the latest thing in imported husbands!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Alan, will you do me a teeny-weeny favor? As you've got to marry in order to live, I wish you'd marry to please me.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: How can I marry somebody else to please you?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Don't marry anybody who'll make you forget me.

div.stage: (If used or not used then continue)

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: But remember, if a dashing widow should claim you, don't accept.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: But if one with a bad temper, and a squeaky voice should claim you, it would make me feel very restful.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: How about me, I need a little rest myself.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Every time you looked at her, I know you'd think of me!

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: The merry widows are here, although they are not all so merry.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Are they pretty?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: They're a group of dreams.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: I'll leave you. Remember, nothing attractive, nothing that will take me from your thoughts! For one second. (EXITS L)

div.stage: (To a strain of MUSIC the WIDOWS ENTER.)

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Here they are, my boy! Now turn on your best personality.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: If they're going to propose to me, I won't know what to say, except this is all so sudden.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Don't hesitate, girls. The one who speaks first gets him. (Xes into Courthouse.)

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Well, ladies, the auction bargain sale is going to begin. Here I am, the answer to any widow's prayer. Will anyone start off the bidding. (Turns to first.) How about you, lady?

sp.speaker: 1st Widow Woman
sp.p: Do you think that all marriages are happy?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: All marriages are happy, it's the living together after marriage that causes all the trouble.

sp.speaker: 1st Widow
sp.p: Before we were married, my husband said he would die for me. And after marriage he was kind enough to do it!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Ah! Lady Dracula speaking! I hope I don't get an offer from you.

sp.speaker: 2nd Widow
sp.p: My next husband must be strong, silent, full of grit, -- able to bear the burden of the day! He will not hear a word said about me, and he will utter no unkind word.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: What you want is a deaf and dumb coal heaver!

sp.speaker: 3d Widow
sp.p: When I was married I didn't do as well as I expected. And to tell you the truth I don't think he did either. I've been married twice, but I think every widow's entitled to her third.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I think you're frank anyway, and you seem to have an even temper.

sp.speaker: 3d Widow
sp.p: Yes, my temper's even, always the same --very nasty!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I believe you're deliberately falsifying it. How did your last husband happen to die?--

sp.speaker: 3rd Widow
sp.p: Oh, I suppose he thought it was the best way out!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I hope you don't claim me. (Turns to 4th) How about you, lady?

sp.speaker: 4th Widow
sp.p: The first month I was married, we lived in a bungalow, called "Ye Lovey Dovey Cot"

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I suppose you changed that afterward to "Ye Battling Arena".

sp.speaker: 5th Widow
sp.p: My husband was a dentist with a sense of humor. But he pulled too many good ones.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: He must have been very easily tickled.

sp.speaker: 5th Widow
sp.p: Yes, he was so ticklish, he couldn't touch his ribs - he had to have them dry-cleaned. But he left me a large fortune.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Step into my office, I want to talk to you. (Takes her aside.) (Converses pantomine)
sp.stage: (Widows surround Alan, and he walks to steps, they follow him)
sp.p: I'll take all your offers into consideration. And you may hear from me later. -- But I doubt it. (EXITS into court house)

sp.speaker: 1st Widow
sp.p: The trouble with you merry widows is, you make love in slow waltz time. You'd better all pop up and start to swing.

div.stage: (THE MERRY WIDOW WALTZ played in swing-time)
(This was done by Abe Lyman and Paul Whiteman and is very effective)
(TOM TOM ENTERS followed by Alan from court house)

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Gone! Alan, the widows have gone without claiming you!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Guess I didn't appear to be as advertised. (Gonzorgo and Roderigo enter up L)

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Shall we proceed?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Wait till I return. There's one more chance! (EXIT up R)

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: (Aside) I wonder if he'll help us.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: Try him.

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: We're in a very embarrassing position.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: And you only can save us from becoming perfectly ridiculous. When we start to execute you, everybody is liable to laugh at us.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I won't!

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: If they find we're not regular executioners, we'll lose the job.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: How can I help you?

sp.speaker: Gonzorgo
sp.p: Since you've got to leave this cold, hard world, will you allow us to send you our way? (Touching warrant) It'll be so much pleasanter than this.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I'll go your way.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.p: Wise boy. Now what would you like in the way of a farewell luncheon. It'll be your very last. Have anything you like.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: I'd like a dish of strawberries.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: But strawberries won't be in season for 6 months!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: That's all right, I'll wait.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: No, now is your time. But I can give you a glass of strawberry wine.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: With a dash of this in it.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Why, it's poison!

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Four drops of that in your wine...

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Just before you start for the scafford...

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: And you'll go into a dreadless sleep.

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Go ahead! I haven't anything to lose. Except my life. (JUDGES, Attendants, widows chorus enter. Jane also)

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Alan, are you living yet?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Yes, but in a few minutes, I will be not yet. (TOM TOM ENTERS UP R. with WIDOW PIPER)

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Stop! Here's another widow! Mother, make Alan our step-father and save his life!

sp.speaker: Piper Children
sp.p: Go ahead ma!

sp.speaker: Widow Piper
sp.p: I can't. It's too late. I'm married.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Married? You said you'd never marry anybody but a hare!

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: And here he is!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: And what made him a hare?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: He dined at a night club, and he dared to go without tipping the waiter. (BARNABY enters)

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Now, Mary my dear--what's this?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: The end of your nephew.

sp.speaker: Barnaby
sp.p: Too bad, too bad. I'm very sorry. (ALL turn away from him) It was my duty. I had to do it. I really had to...Such treatment is hard to bear... (His eyes fall on the tray with the wine glass) Without help. At such a time as this I need encouragement. (Taking glass, drains it) Oh! Oh!

div.stage: (ALL turn. HE falls into the arms of Gonzrgo and Roderigo... who carry him off stage)

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: He has drunk the wine that was intended for me.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Mrs. Barnaby you're a widow!

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: A widow?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Excessive grief has taken Uncle Barnaby from us.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Then Alan is saved! I am a widow, and under your laws I claim him as my husband!

sp.speaker: Alan
sp.p: Mary!
